<h2 id="week-1" class="panel-title">
<a data-toggle="collapse" href="#collapse1">Week 1: 08/22. Introduction</a>
</h2>
</div>
<div id="collapse1" class="panel-collapse collapse in" style="margin:12px">
<p><b>Topics:</b> Introductions and course overview. What is Computational Social Science? Good computing practices.</p>
<p><a href="slides/01-intro.pdf">SLIDES (.pdf): Introduction to the course.</a></p>
<h4>Background reading</h4>
<ul>
<li><p>Lazer, D., Pentland, A. S., Adamic, L., Aral, S., Barabasi, A. L., Brewer, D., ... & Jebara, T. (2009). <a href="http://fowler.ucsd.edu/computational_social_science.pdf">Life in the network: the coming age of computational social science</a>. <i>Science</i>, 323(5915), 721-3.</p>
</li>
<li><p>Golder, S. A., & Macy, M. W. (2014). <a href="http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/full/10.1146/annurev-soc-071913-043145">Digital footprints: Opportunities and challenges for online social research.</a> <i>Annual Review of Sociology</i>, 40(1), 129.</p>
</li>
<li><p>Grimmer, J. (2015). <a href="https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/S1049096514001784">We are all social scientists now: how big data, machine learning, and causal inference work together</a>. <i>PS: Political Science & Politics</i>, 48(1), 80-83.</p>
</li>
<li><p>Nagler, J. (1995). <a href="http://www.jstor.org/stable/420315">Coding style and good computing practices</a>. <i>PS: Political Science & Politics</i>, 28(3), 488-492.</p>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>


<div class="panel-group">
<div class="panel panel-default">
<div class="panel-heading">
<h2 id="week-2" class="panel-title">
<a data-toggle="collapse" href="#collapse2">Week 2: 08/29. Ethics.</a>
</h2>
</div>
<div id="collapse2" class="panel-collapse collapse in" style="margin:12px">

<p><b>Topics:</b> Computational social science: research opportunities and challenges. Overview of theories, methods, and data. Ethics of social science research in the digital age. Big data, big bias? Data collection: automated data collection from the web.</p>
<p><a href="slides/02-big-data.pdf">SLIDES (.pdf): Computational Social Science - Research opportunities and challenges.</a></p>

<h4>Background reading</h4>
<ul>
<li><p>Lazer, D. & and Radford, J. (2017). <a href="http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev-soc-060116-053457">Data ex Machina: Introduction to Big Data.</a> <i>Annual Review of Sociology</i>.</p>
</li>
<li><p><a href="http://www.bitbybitbook.com/en/ethics/">Chapter 6</a> of Salganik, M. (2017). <a href="http://www.bitbybitbook.com/">Bit by Bit: Social Research in the Digital Age.</a> Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press. Open review edition.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<h4>Readings for discussion</h4>
<ul>
<li><p>Kramer, A. D., Guillory, J. E., & Hancock, J. T. (2014). <a href="http://www.pnas.org/content/111/24/8788.short">Experimental evidence of massive-scale emotional contagion through social networks.</a> <i>Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences</i>, 111(24), 8788-8790.<p>
</li>
<li><p>Tufekci, Z. (2014). <a href="https://www.aaai.org/ocs/index.php/ICWSM/ICWSM14/paper/viewFile/8062/8151">Big Questions for Social Media Big Data: Representativeness, Validity and Other Methodological Pitfalls</a>. <i>ICWSM</i>, 14, 505-514.<p>
</li>
</ul>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</h2>
</div>
<div id="collapse3" class="panel-collapse collapse in" style="margin:12px">

<p><b>Topics:</b> Survey research in the digital age. New sampling techniques. Multilevel regression and poststratification.</p>

</div>

<div class="panel-group">

<div class="panel-heading">
<h2 id="week-5" class="panel-title">
<a data-toggle="collapse" href="#collapse5">Week 5: 09/19. Text (I).</a>
</h2>
</div>
<div id="collapse5" class="panel-collapse collapse in" style="margin:12px">

<p><b>Topics:</b> Introduction to automated text analysis. Sources of textual data. String manipulation in R. Regular expressions. Text processing with quanteda. Dictionary methods.</p>

<p><a href="slides/07-text-intro.pdf">SLIDES (.pdf): Introduction to automated text analysis. Dictionary methods applied to sentiment analysis.</a></p>


<h4>Background reading</h4>
<ul>
<li><p>Grimmer, J., & Stewart, B. M. (2013). <a href="https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/political-analysis/article/div-classtitletext-as-data-the-promise-and-pitfalls-of-automatic-content-analysis-methods-for-political-textsdiv/F7AAC8B2909441603FEB25C156448F20">Text as data: The promise and pitfalls of automatic content analysis methods for political texts</a>. <i>Political analysis</i>, 21(3), 267-297.<p>
</li>

</li>
</ul>

<ul>

</li>
<li><p>Tausczik, Y. R., & Pennebaker, J. W. (2010). <a href="http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0261927X09351676">The psychological meaning of words: LIWC and computerized text analysis methods</a>. <i>Journal of language and social psychology</i>, 29(1), 24-54.</p></li>
